predicate.note: Frames file for 'catch' based on sentences in financial subcorpus. Verbnet class get-13.5.1, other framed members include buy, call, find, gain, get, order, pull, reach, and win. Comparison with 'get'.

roleset.name: get

example.name: no giver
example.text: Inexplicably costumed as a rabbinical student, tottering around on lifts, Mr. Shicoff hardly seemed the fellow *trace* to catch a fancy cocotte's eye.

example.name: with giver
example.text: John caught a long fly ball from his two-year old daughter.

roleset.note: Roleset abbreviated from get. Latter examples might be parsed as [a long fly ball from his two-year-old daughter].

example.name: typical usage
example.text: But the government's action, which *trace* caught Jaguar management flat-footed,...

roleset.name: trap

example.name: no trap mentioned
example.text: Program trading itself is merely caught *trace* in the middle of this battle, unfairly labeled as the evil driving force of the marketplace.
example.arg: in the middle of this battle
unfairly labeled as the evil driving force of the marketplace

example.name: with trap
example.text: At the same time it has been caught *trace* in an earnings squeeze .

example.name: metaphorical trap?
example.text: The scope of the improvement in the U.S. business caught some analysts by surprise.
example.arg: The scope of the improvement in the U.S. business

roleset.note: This latter example could be regarded as the attributive 'come upon' sense; at least the tagging is basically the same.

example.name: stated goal
example.text: Meanwhile, Shearson Lehman's Mr. Devario said that, to stay competitive, the U.S. paper industry needs *trace* to catch up with the European industry.

example.name: no goal
example.text: ``They are going *trace* to catch up,'' said David Claridge, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist.

example.name: no audience
example.text: ...its Amiga, which has slick graphics yet has been slow *trace* to catch on.

example.name: with audience
example.text: And, with many of his 70,000 workers, Mr. Smith's damn-the-torpedoes attitude has caught on.

example.name: you can't fool me!
example.text: At one point, the reader is two steps ahead of Marlowe in [*] catching on to a double identity scam -- and Marlowe is supposed to be the pro.
